{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3637887,"name":"Ezra","username":"Strflightmight","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/strflightmight/{size}/261969_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-28T09:50:00.413Z","cooked":"

I was looking into components that could level up our electronics and I stumbled across this, and similar CANbus testers and I was wondering if something like this was usable for FRC‚Äôs devices and if it could actually provide benefits. Has anyone used anything similar/has more knowledge that could be helpful? Are there any other devices or components that could help an intermediate electronics level team?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-05-28T09:50:00.413Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":247,"reads":540,"readers_count":539,"score":1433.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":502487,"topic_slug":"canbus-tester-for-frc","display_username":"Ezra","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.amazon.com/Jhoinrch-Converter-Canable-Adapter-Supports/dp/B0DWRZC2J1?ref_=ast_sto_dp","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Amazon.com: Jhoinrch USB to CAN FD Converter Based on Canable 2.0 CAN USB FD Adapter Supports 5 Mbps : Electronics","clicks":180},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/change-one-letter-of-a-thread-title/466278/103","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Change one letter of a thread title","clicks":7}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62434,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5990 | Programmer, Electronics Lead, and Driver"},"post_url":"/t/canbus-tester-for-frc/502487/1","custom_user_title":"5990 | Programmer, Electronics Lead, and Driver","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3637929,"name":"","username":"senditmel","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/e19adc/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-28T11:55:52.650Z","cooked":"

You would probably be better off with a multimeter to check if the CAN is shorted or if it never reaches its destination. I think this lets you read the CAN signals, but that doesn‚Äôt seem super helpful, as most FRC CAN problems have nothing to do with that and more to do with incorrect wiring. Also, most of the CAN activity can be viewed in the dashboard.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-05-28T12:01:36.026Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":516,"readers_count":515,"score":198.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":502487,"topic_slug":"canbus-tester-for-frc","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":75132,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/canbus-tester-for-frc/502487/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6},{"id":"-1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3637955,"name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","username":"kingc95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-28T12:41:09.152Z","cooked":"

If it‚Äôs designed after the Canable like it states then it would work with CAN 2.0 devices and allow you to use the Phoenix Framework API (motor control for CTRE, older gen devices probably not Krakens, falcons, etc) on something like a raspberry pi or Nvidia Jetson.

As far as testing the ‚Äòhealth‚Äô of a CAN network the current methods of multimeter for continuity, dashboard for bandwidth, and the various tools for changing your device IDs. An additional piece of hardware will not add much in terms of new insights here.

One thing that may be of interest is examining the signals under an oscilloscope and looking for noise in the signal and where it is coming from, I do not know enough to explain how to do this or what to look for though.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-05-28T14:44:19.808Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":465,"readers_count":464,"score":128.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":502487,"topic_slug":"canbus-tester-for-frc","display_username":"Mr. Siefen | 453","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20632,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mr. Siefen"},"post_url":"/t/canbus-tester-for-frc/502487/3","custom_user_title":"Mr. Siefen","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3637998,"name":"Dan Nichols","username":"jnicho15","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jnicho15/{size}/7893_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-28T12:47:30.405Z","cooked":"

Unless you are a Redux fan, it‚Äôs probably not useful.

Again, most FRC CAN issues are with the wiring, and this kind of adapter is for recording data frames, not testing the electrical system.

Except for Redux (which posts their CAN message format here), FRC suppliers don‚Äôt publish the database files for deciding CAN traffic off the wire, for using an adapter like this. You‚Äôd just get a bunch of random bytes. The alternative is to use something like a Phoenix Tuner or Hoot logs, where the Phoenix black-box libraries decode the CAN traffic for you.

Funny story, it used to be pretty straightforward to reverse-engineer the CTRE CAN message format, until REV did it and made CTRE upset, who then promptly obfuscated the format. Much to the dismay of mentors from the automotive industry who are used to sniffing the CAN bus. I‚Äôd much rather use Vector CANalyzer than Phoenix Tuner to live view sensor data, but I can‚Äôt.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-05-28T12:49:02.433Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":402,"readers_count":401,"score":200.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":502487,"topic_slug":"canbus-tester-for-frc","display_username":"Dan Nichols","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.reduxrobotics.com/canspec/Canandmag#messages","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":18}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23941,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 548 Robostangs Electrical & Pneumatics Lead Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/canbus-tester-for-frc/502487/4","custom_user_title":"FRC 548 Robostangs Electrical & Pneumatics Lead Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3638001,"name":"Ada T","username":"cmdada","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cmdada/{size}/230870_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-28T12:50:22.525Z","cooked":"
SparkMAX following loadless Talon Programming
Are you sure? The ‚Äúold‚Äù Talon CAN protocols (that I used here, and that can be found in code on the CTRE github) is no longer in use. Recent Pheonix releases use different, obfuscated packet formats that I haven‚Äôt yet succeeded in reverse engineering.

for anyone that‚Äôs interested

This Video covers what CAN should look like with an oscilloscope, along with what it looks like during common problems.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-05-28T13:07:42.051Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":304,"readers_count":303,"score":90.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":502487,"topic_slug":"canbus-tester-for-frc","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OIMuVVPu2N8","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":26}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":20632,"username":"kingc95","name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":75132,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/canbus-tester-for-frc/502487/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3638084,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-28T14:03:51.779Z","cooked":"

As others have stated, most of the CAN problems are due to wiring issues that can be found using simpler tools and methods. Bad wiring would likely make this tool not detect anything. On very rare occasions, I have encountered dead CAN ports.

This device is more useful to someone developing devices that communicate over a CAN bus and need to know if they have implemented the data protocols correctly.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-05-28T14:03:51.779Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":285,"readers_count":284,"score":92.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":502487,"topic_slug":"canbus-tester-for-frc","display_username":"philso","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15467,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/canbus-tester-for-frc/502487/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3638106,"name":"Nathan Zhou","username":"NathanZhou","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nathanzhou/{size}/225374_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-28T14:30:22.747Z","cooked":"

These CAN debugger are very useful if you are designing your own protocol. However when it comes to wiring issue, these things won‚Äôt help much. All you get when there is a wiring issue is nothing on the screen.

If you are experiencing wiring issue, the fastest method is unplug the battery and measure resistance between your two CAN wire. Normal resistance should be around 60 Ohm. If it is reading 120 Ohm, one termination resistor is missing (normal if you segment your CAN bus to pinpoint the issue). If it is 0 Ohm, it is shorted and if it is several kOhm, there is no termination on the line. Sometimes it is also necessary to check the resistance between each lines to power positive, power ground and chassis and see if anything is shorter to those.

Now in terms of use in FRC, if you want to see the exact data on CAN bus, you don‚Äôt need to go out and buy one of these. If you have any REV CAN connected device, REV Hardware Client do have a built in CAN Data function which could let you see CAN frame.

image1004√ó453 52 KB

However, what the exact meaning of those data various by device manufacture and not all FRC Vendor published their protocol. I had my own CAN implementation on FRC and I had to design my own protocol (on top of FRC specification),

Custom CAN sensor - some good progress Control System
For the past few days I tried to make some CAN sensor using Arduino + mcp2515 and had some good result. There were many past attempt on CD to make custom CAN stuff but none of them had enough documentation. That‚Äôs why I am sharing some of my work. [f82c79cad8da5bf90882fcda3b9d87a] Here are some of the stuff I manage to achieve Analog input from Arduino to roboRIO Digital input from Arduino to roboRIO REV Colour sensor V3 connected to Arduino i2c to roboRIO with fault detection roboRIO con‚Ä¶

Unless you want to do your own stuff or use a coprocessor, the use of such adapter is pretty limited.

Also my personal preference of analyzer is CANalyst-II due to its performance. However, it is pretty hard to source it in North America and the software came with it had horrible English translation.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-05-28T14:35:35.981Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":12,"reads":260,"readers_count":259,"score":207.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":502487,"topic_slug":"canbus-tester-for-frc","display_username":"Nathan Zhou","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.amazon.ca/CANalyst-II-Analyzer-CAN-BUS-Converter-ZLGCANpro/dp/B06XCVR1L2","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"CANalyst-II USB to CAN Analyzer CAN-BUS Converter Adapter Support ZLGCANpro with OBD Plug : Amazon.ca: Electronics","clicks":14},{"url":"https://v6.docs.ctr-electronics.com/en/stable/docs/installation/installation-nonfrc.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Installing Phoenix 6 (non-FRC)","clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/custom-can-sensor-some-good-progress/501764","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Custom CAN sensor - some good progress","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66330,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Fennekinü¶ä is so cute!"},"post_url":"/t/canbus-tester-for-frc/502487/8","custom_user_title":"Fennekinü¶ä is so cute!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3638129,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-28T15:11:32.320Z","cooked":"
NathanZhou:

Sometimes it is also necessary to check the resistance between each lines to power positive, power ground and chassis and see if anything is shorter to those.

We spent about an hour to find where a CAN wire was pressed against a sharp edge. The insulation was pierced, shorting it to the chassis rendering the CAN bus inoperable. The checks for opens, shorts and termination all indicated everything was OK. We only found the fault by bypassing sections of the CAN bus to isolate the fault to one run of wires then replacing the wires.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-05-28T15:11:32.320Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":203,"readers_count":202,"score":60.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":502487,"topic_slug":"canbus-tester-for-frc","display_username":"philso","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15467,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/canbus-tester-for-frc/502487/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3638206,"name":"Chadfrom7226","username":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-28T15:40:27.696Z","cooked":"

If you REALLY want to look at your CAN network quality, you can use CANalyzer or CANoe which can give you detailed information about bus utilization, collisions, quality, that sort of stuff. It‚Äôs expensive, so just borrow it from work

But in reality, if you have 60ohms resistance across the bus, and you have all your devices connected, you should be good to go. Any other issue is most likely just programming or configurations like CAN IDs

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-05-28T15:40:27.696Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":188,"readers_count":187,"score":52.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":502487,"topic_slug":"canbus-tester-for-frc","display_username":"Chadfrom7226","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20021,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/canbus-tester-for-frc/502487/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3638214,"name":"Chadfrom7226","username":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-28T15:41:36.293Z","cooked":"

I just got one of those a few days ago. They seem to work pretty well with python-can but it‚Äôs a weird SL-CAN protocol that you can turn into Socket CAN or use a COM port in windows

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-05-28T15:41:36.293Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":181,"readers_count":180,"score":56.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":502487,"topic_slug":"canbus-tester-for-frc","display_username":"Chadfrom7226","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20021,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/canbus-tester-for-frc/502487/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3638755,"name":"Nathan Zhou","username":"NathanZhou","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nathanzhou/{size}/225374_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-28T19:32:17.962Z","cooked":"

image730√ó592 57.8 KB

I would say the best CAN analyzing tool a team have in hand is the one built in to REV. Even it doesn‚Äôt show utilization, it do show fault (error frame)

If you want a stand alone external anlyzer, grab a REV device that you don‚Äôt use and connect CAN to it. You don‚Äôt need external power to use this CAN Data function as USB will power the device. Only CAN and USB is needed to get it to work.

1df7ed2833bff9a33ab587079dcd77d1280√ó1707 269 KB

and it is smaller than a CANalyst
2ba92dfa1049eaa32728798e479000e1707√ó1280 211 KB

The best part of it is it is completely free (most team should have at some unused REV CAN connected device). Just plug in USB to a REV device and it works. The down side is you are stuck with REV hardware client compare to other anlyzer.

https://canable.io/updater/

CANAble have 2 types of firmware. SL-CAN and Candlelight. To switch mode, you need to flash the firmware using the link above.

Candlelight firmware is better as it use USB protocol. To use it with python-can, you need the right firmware on your adapter using the updater and the right driver (libusb using zadig).

https://python-can.readthedocs.io/en/stable/interfaces/gs_usb.html#supported-platform

SL-CAN is the CAN over Serial mode. This mode had better compatibility but are slower.
https://python-can.readthedocs.io/en/stable/interfaces/slcan.html

The form factor of this adapter varies. But as long as it say CANable, it is the same thing (software side).

And most importantly, your code with python-can needs to be setup correctly to talk to the right adapter at the right mode.

We use a combination of software and a CAN map for diagnostics.
When assembling the robot and finishing up the wiring, make sure to create and end to end map of you bus(es).
By viewing the bus from each end, via Phoenix Configuator on the Rio, a PDH or SparkMax etc., you should be able to see all devices on the bus. If you only see a partial list, typically, the failure is just after the last one.You see on the list. You can verify this by looking at the bus from the other end.And you should be able to see the remaining devices on the bus.
Now that you know where the communication ends, you should be able to find where the error exists much more quickly.

I would also recommend an oscilloscope. Not cheap, but hugely beneficial for seeing things no software will tell you.
Look for clean edges, only small ringing after each edge, and for both CANH and CANL to move. Dominant should be CANH near 3-4v and CANL near 0v, recessive should be both lines near 2v. You can see shorts to ground, shorts between the lines, improper termination, the effects if one line is open somewhere. Quite useful for diagnostics beyond just bus off or data loss

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-05-29T07:15:23.594Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":16,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":99,"readers_count":98,"score":44.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":502487,"topic_slug":"canbus-tester-for-frc","display_username":"Ezra","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":37435,"username":"beedward","name":"Ben Edwards","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/beedward/{size}/111315_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62434,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5990 | Programmer, Electronics Lead, and Driver"},"post_url":"/t/canbus-tester-for-frc/502487/17","custom_user_title":"5990 | Programmer, Electronics Lead, and Driver","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3639521,"name":"Ben Edwards","username":"beedward","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/beedward/{size}/111315_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-29T14:04:44.603Z","cooked":"

The primary characteristics of any oscilloscope are bandwidth and number of channels. Secondary characteristics are sample rate (for modern digital scopes), user interface (knobs? screen size?), trigger system complexity, measurements, protocol decoding, and accessory compatibility. There are more things you can get into, generally you‚Äôll know if you need them.

A good rule of thumb for mixed signal diagnostics (like for CAN) is that your scope bandwidth should be at least 10x your signal clock rate. This allows you to see ringing, rise time issues, reflections and so forth without the scope lying to you.

For CAN FD, then, you need at least 100MHz of bandwidth (10Mbit data rate) and 2 channels.

Handheld scopes are nice for portability but their user interface is almost always awful. If this is your first oscilloscope I would recommend a desktop ‚Äúlunchbox‚Äù form factor with knobs and buttons. This is much easier to use, even though you‚Äôre tied to a wall outlet.

The gold standards for oscilloscopes are from Tektronix, Teledyne-LeCroy, and Keysight. Even for a 2 channel 100MHz scope they will run you thousands of dollars new. The cost of a scope scales primarily with bandwidth & channels. 100 MHz from top tier manufacturers is around $2k, 200 MHz is about $4k, 1 GHz is about $12k. They make faster ones. If you need one of those later in life, you‚Äôll know it, and your company or lab will pay a LOT for it. A 4 channel 10 GHz scope from Tektronix is $170k. And then you pay again for 10 GHz probes, which all by themselves are north of $10k.

If you‚Äôre willing to buy used, look on Ebay/FB Marketplace/local ham radio swap meet for a Tektronix TDS or TBS series scope, at least 2 channels, at least 100 MHz bandwidth. The cheapest you‚Äôll find that are working will be about $200. You‚Äôll have to get probes as well, those will be $30-$50 for a pair of 100MHz probes. For that money, a used Tektronix scope will be easier to use and probably last longer than anything new.

If you would prefer new, look on Digikey or Amazon for a 100 MHz 2 channel scope, benchtop type. Hantek, Rigol, Siglent and GWInstek are okay brands. You‚Äôll pay about the same. The user interface will be a little slower and clunkier. I would not recommend anything cheaper than about $200 new, it will be utter junk and you‚Äôll hate it.

I use a portable OWON HDS2102 scope for CAN diagnostics at events, but the interface is terrible and it‚Äôs not the best quality product. We use the Tek TDS lunchbox scopes at work for basic stuff and have a couple of 1 GHz Teledyne-LeCroy scopes for heavy lifting. But I do mostly embedded systems and motor controls, and so I don‚Äôt need super high bandwidth.
